detail.content: Histopathology Core | Office of Collaborative Science (OCS)                                       Skip to main content                      Patient Care       Faculty & Staff Directory       Events       Careers       Donate                                                                                                                                                                             Office of Collaborative Science (OCS)                    RESEARCH CORES & SHARED RESOURCES                                                                                   Home   Cores and Shared Resources   Pricing   Who We Are                                  Home Cores and Shared Resources Histopathology Core            Print  Email               - A + A                                                                                                                                              Histopathology Core       The Histopathology Core, one component of the Experimental Pathology Shared Resource , provides services, instrumentation and training to facilitate the production of high quality tissue samples for morphological and molecular analyses for both animal model and clinical research. The Histopathology Core is tightly integrated with the Immunohistochemistry (IHC) Core , the second component of the Experimental Pathology Shared Resource.   Services offered by the Histopathology Core include tissue preparation, processing, sectioning and histochemical staining of both animal and fixed human tissues. All human samples are obtained athrough the closely affiliated Human Specimen Resource Center (HSRC) , or other IRB-approved sources. In addition, the Histopathology Core provides instrumentation that is available on a self-serve basis, such as a state-of the-art Laser Dissection Microscope, a microtome, a cryostat and a microscope fitted with a digital camera, and a digital whole slide scanner.       NEW! Digital Whole Slide Scanning   Order Forms   Services       Fees   Acknowledging Us   Contact Us             Contact Us  Phone: 212-263-3888  Email: histopath.core@nyumc.org     Location  Medical Science Building (MSB) 598  NYU Langone Medical Center  550 First Avenue  New York, NY 10016                                                                Announcements   Come visit us in our new location in MSB 598.   Citations   Mallen-St Clair, J. et al., EZH2 couples pancreatic regeneration to neoplastic progression. Genes & development 26, 439-444, (2012).   Nancy, P. et al., Chemokine gene silencing in decidual stromal cells limits T cell access to the maternal-fetal interface. Science 336:1317-21 (2012).   Ntziachristos, P., et al., Genetic inactivation of the polycomb repressive complex 2 in T cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia. NYU Neuroscience Institute Core Faculty | Neuroscience Institute                                     Skip to main content                      Patient Care       Faculty & Staff Directory       Events       Careers       Donate                                                                                                                                                                             Neuroscience Institute                                                                                  Who We Are   What We Do   Training Programs   Resources & Support   Contact Us                                  Home Who We Are Neuroscience Institute Core Faculty            Print  Email               - A + A                                         Who We Are      Neuroscience Institute Core Faculty     open/close   Neuroscience Institute Affliates  Alphabetically   By Research Area   By Department, Institute, or Program   Clinical Centers     Leon Levy Neuroscience Fellows   Neuroscience & Physiology Graduate Students   Neuroscience Institute Administration   Support the Neuroscience Institute                                                                                                    NYU Neuroscience Institute Core Faculty                                          The NYU Neuroscience Institute is home to thirteen core faculty members with laboratories in the Alexandria Center and the Smilow Research Building. Browse their profiles below to learn more about the outstanding research at the Neuroscience Institute. More information about other Neuroscience Institute Affliates can be found by using the links in the menu on the left.            Jayeeta Basu, PhD  – Assistant Professor of Neuroscience & Physiology and the NYU Neuroscience Institute Research Focus: Synaptic and circuit mechanisms of plasticity, learning behaviors and memory processing.          Gyorgy Buzsaki, MD, PhD  – The Biggs Professor of Neuroscience, Neuroscience & Physiology and the NYU Neuroscience Institute Research Focus: Rhythms in neural networks          Jeremy Dasen, PhD  – Associate Professor of Neuroscience & Physiology and the NYU Neuroscience Institute Research Focus: Genetic basis of neural circuit formation and function          Gordon Fishell, PhD  – The Julius Raynes Professor of Neuroscience & Physiology , Director of the Smilow Neuroscience Program, and Associate Director of the NYU Neuroscience Institute Research Focus: Molecular and genetic origins of cortical interneuron diversity          Michael Halassa, MD, PhD  – Assistant Professor of Psychiatry, Neuroscience & Physiology, and the NYU Neuroscience Institute Research Focus: Microcircuits underlying state-dependent regulation of information processing          Dayu Lin, PhD  – Assistant Professor of Psychiatry, Neuroscience & Physiology, and the NYU Neuroscience Institute Research Focus: Neural circuits that underlie social behaviors          Michael Long, PhD  – Assistant Professor of Otolaryngology, Neuroscience & Physiology, and the NYU Neuroscience Institute Research Focus: Cellular and circuit mechanisms of complex, learned motor behaviors          Katherine Nagel, PhD  – Assistant Professor of Neuroscience & Physiology and the NYU Neuroscience Institute Research Focus: Biophysics of sensory processing.          Bernardo Rudy, MD, PhD  – Professor of Neuroscience & Physiology and the NYU Neuroscience Institute Research Focus: Organization and function of neocortical circuits          Dmitry Rinberg, PhD  - Associate Professor of Neuroscience & Physiology, and the NYU Neuroscience Institute Research Focus: Sensory information processing in the behaving animal          James Salzer, MD, PhD  – Professor of Cell Biology and Neurology, and the NYU Neuroscience Institute Research Focus: Interactions between myelin and axons and their disruption in demyelinating disorders          David Schoppik, PhD  - Assistant Professor of Otolaryngology, Neuroscience & Physiology, and the NYU Neuroscience Institute Research Focus: Studying balance to understand the general principles of neural circuit function          Nicholas Stavropoulos, PhD  - Assistant Professor of Neuroscience & Physiology, and the NYU Neuroscience Institute Research Focus: Genetic and molecular mechanisms underlying sleep-wake cycles          Richard Tsien, DPhil  – The Druckenmiller Professor of Neuroscience, Chair of Neuroscience & Physiology , and Director of the NYU Neuroscience Institute Research Focus: Signaling mechanisms linking activity to cytoplasmic events                                                                                           NYU Langone Medical Center       Student Login       Library                 Policies & Disclaimers
